Key Arguments: The government should not have the power to censor views online.
It is not the role of the government to be the arbiters of truth in a democracy.
Controlling speech equates to controlling thought, which undermines personal agency and informed decision-making.
Governments and their agencies are imperfect and distant from the origin of ideas, making them unsuitable to wield such power.
Policing ideas and thoughts would require vast resources and could punish exemplary community members.
Pushing freedom of thought underground is more dangerous than open public discussion.
Notable Quotes: It is never the place of government to be the arbiters of truth and such a concept is simply incompatible with a democracy.
To control one’s speech is to control one’s thought.
Government cannot bestow this level of power upon itself. It is an illegitimate assumption of power, and nothing more.
